title: Joint Source-Environment Adaptation for Deep Learning-Based Underwater Acoustic Source Ranging
author: Dariush Kari (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Andrew C. Singer (Stony Brook University), ...
relevance_why: The methods proposed for domain adaptation and uncertainty estimation can be beneficial for improving robustness in various audio processing tasks, such as audio restoration or enhancement, particularly in challenging environments.
background: The paper addresses the challenge of adapting a deep learning model for underwater acoustic localization to environments where training data is not available, using unsupervised techniques.
contribution: This paper introduces a joint source-environment adaptation framework that combines pre-trained model outputs with an energy-based estimation to enhance localization performance under environmental shifts, achieving improved generalization.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods like matched field processing are limited by requiring access to training datasets for adapting to new environments, hindering their deployment in real-world situations.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing techniques by employing a source-free domain adaptation method that considers the structure of the incoming acoustic signals to make localization predictions without needing retraining.

key_innovation: The integration of a classification model with a probabilistic treatment of source power estimation allows for more confident and robust localization outputs.
real_world_impact: By significantly improving underwater acoustic localization under environmental changes, this approach can enhance applications in ocean monitoring, underwater navigation, and search-and-rescue operations.
limitations: The study does not thoroughly address the performance of the model in extremely variable and unpredictable environmental conditions.

new_terms.source hypothesis transfer (SHOT): **Source hypothesis transfer (SHOT)** is a method for unsupervised domain adaptation that allows a trained model to adjust its feature extraction process without access to training data from the target domain.
